item.title: Economic Systems & Terms
item.description:
Thank you to all the people who have visited the site this week! I would love to hear what you think, so please email if you can.

Today’s addition to the site: if you are not well-schooled in economic terminology, I’ve put together a quick cheat sheet for you to reference. This is definitely one of the longer lists of definitions I plan to put up. It is not in any particular order yet, so please browse the list to find the particular term you are looking for.

item.title: Book Notes: The World That Trade Created
item.description:
A while back I needed to distill the main points of this book to present in a course I was taking - I thought I’d share them here. (To download these notes as a pdf, click here: World Trade Created Notes Organizer.pdf)

Pomeranz, Kenneth, and Steven Topik. The World That Trade Created: Society, Culture, and the World Economy, 1400 to the Present. Armonk, NY: M.E. Sharpe, 2006.

1. Through the Creation of Market Conventions
-Economic activities are social acts that bring groups with very different ideas together.
-Intensification of trade in this period led to increasing agreements on trade conventions.
-Trade diasporas organized trade until colonialism.

2. Transport Tactics
-Transport costs limited the size of cities.
-The railroad and steamships brought the world closer together and elevated manufacturers and financiers over merchants.
-Technology allowed people to keep in touch with home, and ended the necessity of integration.

3. Economic Culture of Drugs
-What has changed over time is not the value, but the definition of drug.
-Governments eventually legalized many so they could tax them.
-Colonial empires were built on the foundation of drug trades.
-Drugs have been both the foundation and bane of states.

4. Commodities in World Trade
-As specific commodities became global, their values and meanings changed from what they had been locally.
-New global commodities often took on associations antithetical to their natural properties.
-Consuming societies tried to synthesize replacements and/or transplant them.

5. Economics of Violence
-Relationships between violence and entrepreneurship have always existed.
-Warfare and economic growth are often not contradictory.
-Warfare has often been the mother of invention.
-Financing war without participating is also quite profitable.

6. Making Modern Markets
-For there to be a true world economy, laws and practices have to be predictable and universal.
-Standardization & impersonal relations were the key.
-Gold and silver became the money standards.
-Industrialization has caused people to trust distant logos more than local production.

7. World Trade, Industrialization & De-Industrialization
-Very few countries have instituted free trade.
-Industrialization in a society depends on a sharp increase in trade.
-Because industrialization coincided with imperialism, we can never know how much industry-increased trade was lost.

(summary originally created 2006)
